Setting up ssh key for github

You know ssh key? No I don’t.

Only used it once on a parallel computing class and nevermore. You know a ÂíåËîºÂ∞èËÄÅÂ§¥ who has been hired form a Tokyo Univerity associate professor position. Sometimes I even doubt that you get bald and a big belly after years of coding experience. In his class we are required to get access to the university super computer. To get authorized, ssh keys are used to grant our personal computers to the gurdian at the door.

When I was young and a sad mathematics major, I fantasize about programmers. Now I basically do coding everday, so I fantasize about mathematicians. The most thing one dumb mathematics majoy may fantasize about programmers, is maybe the largest dating site among males, github.

Politically incorrect joke huh. No respect for female programmers, but high on the patriarchic pyrimaid thus inherently shines the smart people golden light. Github is a web extension of the Git project, and gradually becomes the top journal for open source software development.

So let’s talk about git. Git is a tool for version control. I’m not so familiar with the programming terms like brach, stack, but git can help it when I’m so unsure whether to delete or to revise a paragraph on tex. Yes, git saves my revise on the project whenever I make a commit.

I don’t even know I will need a ssh key when pushing the local files to github webside. Say, without a sort of authentification, anybody can now push to a repositry owned by anybody……????? OK. SSH is a key to my github web door. Let’s customize our key, and the lock.

SSH key is stored in ~/.ssh folder (macOS). Check out if you already have the keys using:

$ls -al ~/.ssh

If not, run the following codes to create the key:

ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096 -C "your_email@example.com"

Upload the public key to GitHub SSH settings, and you can access the repo locally since authority already granted.
